channel.title: Set example :: CIS 301 Textbook
channel.description: Claim: If $n$ is a positive integer greater than or equal to 2, then a set with $n$ elements has $\dfrac{n(n-1)}{2}$ possible subsets of size 2. We will refer to this claim as $P(n)$. Try it out Suppose $n = 3$, and our set contains the elements $(a, b, c)$. There are 3 possible subsets of size 2: $(a, b)$, $(a, c)$, and $(b, c)$. We also have that $\dfrac{3(3-1)}{2} = 3$.
